She has been selling assorted products in addition to working at an elementary school. She started to sell beauty products 8 years ago, thanks to a group of friends who invited her to join. From then on, she has been selling products to her acquaintances little by little, increasing her clientele via the elementary school, where she has a lot of contacts.

She is requesting a loan of $575.00 USD, which will be repaid in 6 months, so that she can obtain merchandise and fill her customers’ orders, which she has not been able to do because of lack of funds.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer.

Carmen inició el negocio porque siempre ha estado sola y ha tenido que buscar la manera de mantener a sus hijos, y desde siempre ha vendido cosas de diversos productos a la par del trabajo que tiene en una escuela primaria. Comenzó hace 8 años a vender los productos de belleza gracias a que un grupo de amigas la invito a formar parte de ellas, y la convencieron y a partir de allí ha ido vendiendo poco a poco entre sus conocidas y ha podido incrementar sus clientes porque en la escuela tiene muchos conocidos y entre ellos puede colocar sus productos y aumentar sus ventas.

Solicita un crédito por US $575 que pagara en 6 meses para poder surtir varios pedidos de mercancía que tiene pendientes y que no ha podido entregar por falta de recursos.

loans.use: Purchase merchandise

loans.name: Rose's Mamboleo Group

texts.en:
Rose is 22 years old and is a married woman with a 3-year-old child. Rose owns a small salon that she started in 2006. Every day, she works from 10am to 6pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $62 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more salon items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members, Mwajuma and Aisha, who sell clothing and food.

loans.use: To buy more salon items for her business.

loans.name: Sesilia

texts.en:
Mambo from Dar es Salaam, Tanzania! This is 30-year-old Sesilia K.. She is married and has 3 children aged 3, 9, and 13. In 2004 Sesilia established her phone accessories business. Sesilia requires a loan in order to purchase additional stocks of phone chargers, cases, batteries, and credit vouchers. She thanks you for your support.

Despite being a "developing" country (forgive the label; there remains no consensus on an acceptable definition), it is amazing how many people have mobile phones in Tanzania and in Africa in general. Not just professionals, but grandmas in villages, school kids, and street sellers. It can probably be attributed to a number of factors, led by the fact that it is the only form of phone communication available to most people because there are few landlines, and followed closely by how relatively cheap mobile phones are here.

loans.use: To purchase additional stocks of phone accessories, such as chargers, batteries, cases, and credit vouchers

loans.name: Cecilia

texts.es:
Cecilia started her business because she has always liked sewing. At first, she only did jobs for her family, but later she started to provide services for other people. This business has been optimal for her because she is doing something that she loves, and at the same time, she is making money to help her husband cover the family expenses.

She started her business 20 years ago, and has been sewing her whole life. Even though she lives in an impoverished area, people seek her services because they like her work and she always completes her job on time. She has always worked from home, and wants to keep doing so because she can take care of her household matters and work at the same time, which she really likes.

She is requesting a loan of $500.00 USD, which will be repaid in 6 months. This loan will help her purchase fabric, thread, buttons, and zippers, the materials she uses most, because it is necessary to have them at hand.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer.

Cecilia inició el negocio porque siempre le ha gustado la costura y inicialmente solo hacia trabajos para su familia, pero ya después empezó a darle el servicio a otra gente y le dio buen resultado porque hace algo que le gusta y a la vez gana dinero para ayudar a su esposo con los gastos de la familia. Comenzó con el negocio hace 20 años, y ya tiene toda una vida haciendo costuras y aunque vive en un lugar modesto la gente de todas maneras me busca porque les gusta su manera de trabajar y siempre tiene a tiempo el trabajo de las prendas que le traen. el negocio siempre lo ha tenido en su casa y piensa seguir allí porque le da la facilidad de no descuidar la casa y a la vez trabajar en lo que realmente me gusta.

Solicita un préstamo por US $500 que pagara en 6 meses. Este crédito e servirá para poder comprar telas, hilos, botones y cierres porque son los materiales que mas usa y es necesario tener el material a la mano

loans.use: Purchase sewing materials

loans.name: Juliana

texts.en:
Juliana is thirty eight years old and the mother of two children. She has been selling washing powder for two years. She buys the product in bulk from Accra and resells them to the retail market by carrying loads on the head to sell from place to place.

She wants to use loan to buy more washing powder to increase her inventory and to avoid price hikes. She is a member of the group called “Nyame wo Tum” (meaning "God has power"). Members guarantee for each other as social collateral to repay the loan. Juliana’s photo was taken during the group’s meeting.

loans.use: To buy more cartons of washing powder

loans.name: Mashaka

texts.en: Mambo from Dar es Salaam, Tanzania! This is 23-year-old Mashaka Y.. She is married and has 2 children aged 1 and 6. In 2006 Mashaka established her cosmetics business. Working 6 days a week and 9 to 12 hours a day, she earns about US$170 every month from this business. She is assisted by her husband. Mashaka has already received and successfully repaid 1 loan from SELFINA, and now she requires a new loan in order to purchase additional stocks of lipsticks, makeup, and hair extensions. In the future, Mashaka plans to diversify her business. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: To expand her range of makeup, lipsticks, and hair pieces

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Sero Lease and Finance Ltd. (SELFINA) - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en:
Agnes is 35 years old and is a married woman with 3 children, ages 18, 12 and 3 years old. Agnes sells cassava, vegetable and bananas. She started in 1986. Every day, she works from 4am to 3pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $30 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more cassava, bananas and vegetables for her business.

loans.use: To buy more cassava, bananas and vegetables for her business.

loans.name: Dora Alicia

texts.es:
Dora started her own business because ever since she has been on her own, she had to work as much as she could due to the fact that her current job as a housekeeper does not generate enough income for her.

She started selling food from home 6 years ago, and ever since then, she has expanded her business so much that has received more patrons, who in turn recommend her restaurant to other people. It is a joy for her to work in this business because she loves to cook, and what better way to earn a living than doing what one loves. Additionally, she sells clothing at a local market place, which is also helpful for her because she looks for places where there is disposable income so that her merchandise can be sold quickly. These two jobs help supplement her income, and thanks to them, she has been able to cover the household expenses.

She is requesting a loan of $975.00 USD, which she will repay in 6 months. This loan will help her purchase more clothing and will also allow her to prepare more meals, thus increasing her profits.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer.

Dora inició el negocio porque al quedarse sola tuvo que trabajar en todo lo que pudiera, ya que el trabajo que tiene actualmente no le deja mucho dinero, trabaja como empleada domestica y el sueldo es muy bajo.

Comenzó su negocio hace mas de 6 años vendiendo comida en su casa, y desde entonces le ha ido bien abriendo mas su negocio de tal manera de que mas gente la conoce y la recomienda con otras personas. Es muy grato trabajar en esto porque a le gusta cocinar y que mejor que ganar dinero haciendo lo que a uno le gusta. Además de esto también vende ropa en los tianguis y de igual manera le funciona porque busca lugares donde hay afluencia y la ropa se logra vender rápidamente. Estos dos trabajos le han ayudado a complementar el empleo que tiene y gracias a esto ha podido sostener su casa y los gastos que va teniendo.

Solicita un préstamo por US $975 que pagara en 6 meses. Este crédito le servirá para poder comprar más paquetes de ropa y también para poder hacer mas comidas y darle movimiento al dinero obteniendo mayores ganancias.

loans.use: Purchase merchandise

loans.name: Theresah

texts.en:
Theresah is thirty eight years old and she has two children. She has a beauty salon and also prepares and sells batik, tye & dye materials. She wants to use her loan to buy more calico material to prepare more batik, and to buy hair creams and other supplies for her beauty salon.

Theresah is a member of the group called “Nyame wo Tom” (meaning "God has power"). Members of the group agree in principle to guarantee for each other as social collateral to repay the loan. Theresah’s photo was taken during the group’s meeting.

loans.use: To buy more fabrics for batik, and dye and hair products for her beauty salon

payments.comment: Correction due to overpayment for business 47378

loans.name: Sandra Guadalupe

texts.es:
Sandra started her business because she needed to help her husband cover the family expenses. They have a newborn child, which means they have to buy many essentials, such as diapers, milk, food, as well as pay for other household expenses. Her husband’s low income makes it difficult to purchase these necessities. She therefore started her clothing business 3 years ago, when her baby was born because she immediately realized that the expenses would grow. There was no other alternative other than getting a job, but she wanted to get a job that would allow her to be close to her son. Thanks to this business, she can balance both working and looking after her child, which puts her at ease.

She is requesting a loan of $575.00 USD, which she will repay in 6 months. This loan will allow her to purchase more merchandise for the season and offer her customers a greater selection of products.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer.

Sandra inició el negocio porque tiene que ayudar a su esposo con los gastos de la casa, ya que tienen un bebe recién nacido y son muchas las cosas que hay que comprar entre pañales, leche, alimentos y además los gastos de la casa; cosas que con el sueldo de su esposo no alcanza para poder comprarlas. Comenzó hace tres años con la venta de ropa cuando nació el bebe, ya que de inmediato se dio cuenta que los gastos iban a ser grandes y no hubo otra alternativa que comenzar a trabajar pero tenia que ser un trabajo que le permitiera estar al lado de su hijo. Gracias a este negocio puede mezclar ambos y no hay problema además que le permite estar mas tranquila.

Solicita un préstamo por US $575 que pagara en 6 meses. Este crédito le va a servir para poder comprar más mercancía de temporada y tener bien surtido para ofrecer variedad a su clientela.

loans.use: Purchase merchandise

loans.name: Jose Jesus

texts.es:
José started his business because he needed to support his wife somehow, and what better way to do so than selling clothing and footwear. He works in several market places, which allows him to work 7 days a week.

He started selling at market places 7 years ago, and since then he has not quit the business because it generates good profits. He cannot slow down his sales because of the serious economic crisis and because the expenses never stop accumulating. He currently sells in several market places and offers apparel at a good price so that his customers can keep buying from him because the competition is stiff.

He is requesting a loan of $300.00 USD, which will be repaid in 6 months. He will use this loan to purchase merchandise.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer.

José inició el negocio porque tiene que mantener a su pareja de alguna manera y que mejor que tener su propio negocio de venta de ropa y calzado. Trabajo en varios tianguis de la ciudad y eso le permite tener ventas todos los días de la semana.

Comenzó hace mas de 5 años con las ventas en los tianguis y desde allí no ha dejado el negocio porque le esta dando buenas ganancias y no puede darse el privilegio de aflojar en las ventas porque la crisis esta muy aguda y los gastos nunca paran. Actualmente vende en varios tianguis y ofrece su ropa a buen precio para que la misma gente le siga comprando porque la competencia en este tipo de negocios es muy dura.

Solicita un préstamo por US $300 que pagara en 6 meses. Este crédito lo va a apoyar para surtir mercancía.

loans.use: Purchase merchandise

loans.name: Evelyne

texts.en: Mambo from Dar es Salaam, Tanzania! This is 36-year-old Evelyne M.. She is married and has 2 children aged 4 and 9. In 2004 Evelyne established her communications business, where she provides telephone and computer services. Evelyne requires a loan in order to purchase additional phone credit vouchers and computer accessories. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: To purchase additional phone credit vouchers in bulk, as well as computer accessories

loans.name: Isaac

texts.en:
Isaac is forty three years old. He is married and he has been in the welding and fabrication business for ten years. He wants to use his loan to buy more scrap metal to manufacture coal pots, dustbins, dust trays, etc. He hopes that income from this loan will enable him to support his wife's venture to start working to earn additional income for the family.

He is a member of the group called “Nyame wo Tum” (meaning "God has power"). This photo of Isaac was taken during a group meeting.

loans.use: To buy more scrap metal for welding and fabrication

loans.name: Betty

texts.en:
Betty is forty three years old and the mother of two children. One of the children is currently in school. She has been selling ladies’ shoes, jewelry, and sewing materials from Togo. She wants to use her loan to buy more products in order to increase her inventory and to avoid price hikes in the products.

Betty is a member of the group called “Nyame wo Tum” (meaning "God has power"). Members agree in principle to guarantee for each other as social collateral to repay the loan.

loans.use: To buy more ladies shoes, jewelry, and sewing materials

payments.comment: Correction due to underpayment for business 47383

loans.name: Ana

texts.en:
Mambo from Dar es Salaam, Tanzania! This is 28-year-old Ana M.. She is married and has no children. She has 2 dependents, who live with her because they are her sister-in-law's children. In 2006 Ana established her café business. Ana requires a loan in order to purchase utensils and ingredients, such as rice, oil, and beans, in bulk. She thanks you for your support.

When you see a SELFINA entrepreneur whose business title is "restaurant" or "café," you may have to adjust your mental image of what that is. A local restaurant or café in Tanzania usually consists of a rough wooden table and some long, wooden benches, with the sky as a ceiling. Such places don’t even appear in the Lonely Planet’s budget guide, but if you’re looking for a cheap and tasty meal and someone to have a chat with, this is the place to be. The food is all local: rice, ugali (a hot, sticky dough, made from maize flour), and plantain (a cooked savory banana), all served with beans, vegetables, meat, and a variety of yummy sauces.

loans.use: To purchase additional ingredients and utensils for her café

loans.name: Elizabety

texts.en:
Mambo from Dar es Salaam, Tanzania! This is 40-year-old Elizabety M.. She is single and has 4 children aged between 7 and 21. She has 2 dependents. In 2004 Elizabety established her liquor store business. Elizabety requires a loan in order to purchase additional stocks of beer and soft drinks. She thanks you for your support.

It is said that Coca Cola® is one of the most recognized symbols or "words" in the world. And it’s true. Even in the most remote villages in Africa, there is usually some kind of "bar" selling Coke, Fanta, and Guiness (Pepsi has made it to most African capitals but not to the rural areas, but I’m sure they’re working on it!). The hot weather makes soft drinks all the more appealing: a very cheap marketing tool. All of which explains why selling soft drinks is such a popular venture, whether you’re the CEO of Coca Cola Ltd in the United States or a micro-entrepreneur in Tanzania!

loans.use: To purchase additional stocks of beer and soft drinks in bulk

loans.name: Comfort

texts.en:
Comfort is forty eight years old and she has two children. One of the children is in school. She has been selling sewing materials, such as polyester, and linen, and other materials that are used for sewing school uniforms, to school children in her community for three years.

Comfort wants to use her loan to buy more material to increase her current inventory, because parents will need material for school uniforms as soon as school resumes after vacation.

She is a member of the "Commitment" group. Members agree to guarantee for each other to repay the loan.

loans.use: To buy more sewing materials, like linen, polyester, and buttons

payments.comment: Correction due to overpayment for business 47386

loans.name: Lucy

texts.en: Mambo from Dar es Salaam, Tanzania! This is 25-year-old Lucy A.. She is single and has 2 children aged 3 and 8. She also has 2 dependents. In 2000 Lucy established a poultry business, selling eggs. Lucy requires a loan in order to purchase additional stocks of eggs in bulk. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: To purchase additional stocks of eggs in bulk for resale

loans.name: Tungulilege

texts.en:
Mambo from Dar es Salaam, Tanzania! This is 40-year-old Tungulilege S.. She is married and has 4 children aged between 14 and 24. In 1994 Tungulilege established her fruit and vegetables business. Tungulilege requires a loan in order to purchase additional stocks of fruit and vegetables in bulk. She thanks you for your support.

When you walk down the streets of Dar, you are greeted at almost every corner by a stall or wheelbarrow full of mangoes, pineapples, bananas, or sugarcane. For customers, these luscious fruits provide welcome refreshment from the searing heat, and for the sellers a regular, if limited, income.

loans.use: To purchase additional stocks of fruits and vegetables in bulk

loans.name: Dorothy

texts.en:
Dorothy is thirty years old and the mother of three children. Two of the children are in school. Dorothy sells vegetables, such as tomatoes, garden eggs (eggplant), and peppers, and vegetable oil and palm oil. She wants to use her loan to buy more oil and fresh vegetables to avoid price hikes and to increase her inventory.

Dorothy is member of the group called "Commitment." Members agree to guarantee for each other as social collateral to repay the loan.

loans.use: To buy more vegetable oil, palm oil and vegetables

payments.comment: Correction due to overpayment for business 47389

loans.name: Diana

texts.en:
Charcoal is one of the main sources of fire in most Ghanaian homes. This has created large market and demand for it.

Diana, a thirty-year-old mother with three children, has been selling charcoal for eight years. Her charcoal business has been supporting her family. She wants to use her loan to buy more charcoal, because, as she reports, she is running out of stock.

Diana is a member of the Commitment group. Members of the group agree in social principle to guarantee for each other to re pay the loan.

loans.use: To buy charcoal

loans.name: Evelyn

texts.en:
Evelyn is thirty two years old and she has four children. All of the children are in school. Evelyn has been operating a grocery store in her community for ten years. Her operation has become the source of her family's income. She wants to use her loan to increase her inventory and avoid price hikes in the products. She believes this loan will help her to save for the children’s education.

Evelyn is a member of the group called "Commitment." Members agree in principle to guarantee for each other as social collateral to repay the loan.

loans.use: To buy more grocery products, such as vegetable oils, tin fish, canned milk, and oats

payments.comment: Correction due to underpayment for business 47391

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy a printer, film, ink, and photographic paper so that he may offer complete service including printing the photos in his photography business.

loans.name: José Eusébio

texts.fr:
Very early on, this young farmer invested himself in market gardening. His rich experience in this sector is worthy of his customers, gained as well by the quality of his produce, including melons, which helps in strengthening the population nutritionally. In applying for this loan, he wants to buy seeds and fertilizers to boost his production and to meet the ever-growing demand of his customers.

Translated from French by Daniel Kuey, Kiva volunteer

Ce jeune agriculteur s'est trés tôt investi dans le maraichage. Sa riche expérience dans le secteur lui vaut une clientéle acquise à sa cause du fait aussi de la qualité de ses produits dont les melons qui participent au renforcement nutritionnel des populations. En sollicitant ce prêt , il veut acheter des semences et des intrants pour booster sa production et répondre à la demande sans cesse croissante de ses clients.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers and seeds

loans.name: Comité 29 De Setiembre Group

texts.en:
The Committee of Entrepreneuring Women is a program carried out by Fundación Paraguaya which targets groups of enterprising women who create a village bank through which they receive assistance in terms of loans. The main goal is to give them the opportunity to carry out economic activities which enable them to live in dignity and contribute to a better quality of life in their homes. Lending to poor women creates a cascading effect that brings social and economic benefits to a whole family, and thus to the entire community. What is more, the sense of belonging to a group gives these poor women, as members of a Committee, the energy and motivation to reach success.

The Committee “29 de setiembre” (September 29th) is formed of a group of 20 women who live in Limpio. A woman who wanted to become member of another Committee in Villa Elisa city could not make it because she was not living in the same town. As a result she contacted 19 other women living in the same town (Limpio) and convinced them to form another group. That is how “29 de septiembre” (September 29th) was born. Today the Commitee is on its 8th loan cycle and they can request loans ranging from 100.000 to 1.600.000 guaranies (US$ 25 to 400) per member.

Among the businesses these women run are: despensas (grocery stores), sewing shops, sales of cheese, food, drinks, jewelry, cloth, fruits, vegetables, lingerie, and sheets. The money provided by the loan will be used for the purchase of lingerie, meat, vegetables, fruits, jewelry, candies, fabrics, thread, cloth and others.

loans.use: Purchase of lingerie, meat, vegetables, fruits, jewelry, candies, fabrics, thread, cloth and others

loans.name: Nilsa

texts.en:
Nilsa Rosalía T. (35) lives with her partner; the couple has a son who attends high school. Nilsa’s boyfriend works as a taxi driver, helping her to generate more income.

Ten years ago Nilsa decided to create a self-employment. Firstly she started selling fruits and vegetables in a little store in front of her house. Then Nilsa had to stop working since she had a heart problem and she needed a surgery followed by a long period of recovery. Consequently, she closed the store. Despite these hard times and her unhealthy situation, Nilsa never gave up. And when her condition improved she opened the grocery store and continued working with full energy. Today, she offers a wide variety of products to large numbers of customers. The grocery store is located in a neighborhood where the government established many homeless families who had nowhere to go.

It is worth mentioning that Nilsa is studying at nursing school. Nilsa’s biggest dream is to finish school and become a nurse in order to help her community.

She needs this loan to increase the number of sales at her grocery store. The products she will buy with the loan are sugar, rice, pasta, breads, drinks, candies, and cleaning products among others.

loans.use: Purchase of sugar, rice, pasta, breads, drinks, candies, and cleaning products among others.

loans.name: Angela

texts.en:
Angela Josefina F. (36) is the single mother of a thirteen-year-old daughter. Both live together and Angela is very concerned with the education of her daughter. She sends her to school and is very strict with academic performance.

Six years ago Angela decided open a restaurant near one of the most important ports in the country, ”port Feniz”. She says: “ I am very proud of my achievements during these six years”.

When the port’s construction began, Angela used to cook and then bring the dishes from her house to the construction site to her relatives who were working there. There, the demand for her food increased and everyone working there became Angela’s customers. When the construction finished, one of the owners of the port offered Angela a restaurant where she could cook and sell her food for employers and drivers of the zone. Angela was more than happy and she accepted the proposal.

Angela says: “ I know I am a very lucky person. I am extremely grateful. Thanks to this income I generate here, I can give my daughter a good level of education. In addition, I can help my mother.”

The money provided by the loan will be invested in the purchase of chicken, meat, flour, oil, pasta, rice and drinks.

loans.use: Purchase of chicken, meat, flour, oil, pasta, rice and drinks

loans.name: Trabajadoras Group

texts.es:
The members of the Hard-working communal bank are natives of the town of Santiago of Atitlan. The people of Santiago of Atitlan are very traditional. They preserve their culture even today. As can be seen in the photo, the women dress with the typical suit of the area that consists of a blouse or embroidered dress, a short or long skirt, a cinch or strap and a perraje or scarf. In many towns the tradition is no longer seen so well preserved as in Santiago.

Another interesting aspect of the town where these women live is that some years ago the population was harshly affected by Hurricane Stan. On that occasion, due to the storm, the town was cut off; the roadways were completely closed and the people went for a long time without access to drinking water and fresh food.

Santiago of Atitlan is a town touched by the art. There are many jewelers, weavers, designers and painters at present living in this area. Inside the “Workers” group all the associates work with weavings. Half of the group works weaving embroidered dresses in looms that are tied at one end to their waist. The waist loom technique has passed down from generation to generation. The majority of women begin to learn to weave before the age of ten years approximately.

The other half of the group do embroidery. As can be seen in the photo they make designs of flowers and birds. The time that it takes a woman to embroider an embroidered dress depends exclusively on the work. For example, an embroidered dress that is completely embroidered such as that of the third lady from the left can take three months, while an embroidered dress that is not embroidered entirely like that of the first lady on the right can take an artisan from three to four weeks. The profits can vary from 15 dollars to fifty dollars, depending on the embroidered dress.

Competition is very tough in Santiago due to the high number of artisans, nevertheless these women can do well. The loan is a very useful tool that they can utilize to invest in their business and to make it more profitable since they can buy the thread wholesale or hire labor. If we support them, we are going to give them the opportunity to be noticed and to do well. Support them!

Translated from Spanish by B, Kiva Volunteer.

Las integrantes del banco comunal Trabajadoras son oriundas del pueblo Santiago de Atitlan. La gente de Santiago de Atitlan es muy tradicional, ellos hasta el día de hoy preservan su cultura. Como se puede ver en la foto, las mujeres están vestidas con el traje típico del área que consiste en la blusa o huipil, corte o falda larga, cincho o correa y un perraje o bufanda. En muchos pueblos ya no se ve la tradición tan preservada como en Santiago.

Otro aspecto interesante del pueblo donde habitan estas mujeres es que hace unos años la población fue duramente afectada por la tormenta Stan. En dicha ocasión, debido a la tormenta el pueblo estuvo aislado, las vias de tránsito estaban completamente clausuradas y la gente estuvo por mucho tiempo sin acceso a agua potable y a comida fresca.

Santiago de Atitlan es un pueblo tocado por el arte. Hay muchos joyeros, tejedores, diseñadores y pintores actualmente viviendo en esta área. Dentro del grupo las Trabajadoras todas las clientas trabajan con tejidos. La mitad del grupo trabaja tejiendo huipiles en telares de cintura. La técnica de telar de cintura se ha pasado de generación en generación. La mayoría de mujeres empiezan ha aprender a tejer antes de los diez años aproximadamente.

La otra mitad del grupo son bordadoras. Como se puede ver en la foto ellas tienden a bordar flores y aves. El tiempo que toma una mujer en bordar un huipil depende exclusivamente del trabajo. Por ejemplo, un huipil que está completamente bordado como el de la tercera señora contando desde la izquierda puede demorar hasta tres meses, mientras que un huipil que no está bordado enteramente como el de la primera señora contando desde la derecha puede tomarle a una artesana de tres a cuatro semanas. Las ganancias pueden variar entre 15 dólares a cincuenta dólares, dependiendo del huipil.

La competencia es muy dura en Santiago debido al alto número de artesanas, sin embargo estas mujeres pueden salir adelante. El crédito es una herramienta muy útil que ellas pueden utilizar para invertir en su negocio y hacerlo más rentable ya que pueden comprar el hilo por mayor o contratar mano de obra. Si nosotros las apoyamos vamos a darles la oportunidad a destacarse y salir adelante. ¡Apoyémoslas!

loans.use: To buy thread wholesale and hire labor for their business making traditional embroidered dresses.

loans.name: Parromero Group

texts.es:
San Jose Chacaya is a rural community in the high plains of Guatemala. It is difficult to conceive the idea that women that have been so marginalized from the social, economic, and political system of the country have access to a service as modern as credit. In their town they heard about a lady called America that works on a project in which they give fast loans with dependable and low interest. That "lady" is America Chiyal, a loan agent that works for Friendship Bridge. The women that make up the group joined to form the communal bank and once they had formed said unit they contacted America.

The Parromeras contacted the institution because they need a loan to enlarge the amount of capital for their business. Half of the group is going to invest their loan in the breeding and sale of chickens. Some are going to buy chickens already grown to feed for some weeks and then sell. Others are going to buy the chickens already grown to cut up and sell in the market, while others are going to buy the chickens already cut up and plucked to sell in the market. Juana Martinez says that she not only plans to invest her loan in the breeding of chickens, but she also plans to buy piglets to grow fat and then sell in the market, and finally she also embroiders typical blouses. One is surprised by the versatility of many of these women.

The other half of the group is divided into 3 parts. Three women sell vegetables in the market. They will invest their loan in the purchase of carrots, huisquil (a type of squash), cabbage, onions, tomatoes, lettuce, and avocado, among other vegetables. Two women work with a foot loom to make short and long traditional skirts. Usually, only men work in the looms owing to the force required to work the loom. The last group works embroidering traditional blouses of their towns.

The dream of the women of Parromero is to grow their business so that they do not have to depend on debt to have a profitable business and so that they can generate sufficient income to invest in their business and to cover the needs of their families. Inside this communal bank there are many women with the drive of Juana Martinez, nevertheless many of these women battle alone. That is why, if we give them a hand, they are going to feel that they are not alone in their fight against poverty.

Translated from Spanish by B, Kiva Volunteer.

San Jose Chacaya es una comunidad retirada en el altiplano de Guatemala. A uno se le haría difícil concebir la idea de que mujeres que han estado tan marginalizadas del sistema político, económico y social del país tengan acceso a un servicio tan moderno como el crédito. Ellas escucharon en su pueblo sobre una “señora” llamada América que trabaja en un proyecto en el cual dan créditos rápidos, con intereses bajos y confiables. Esa “senora” es America Chiyal, una agente de crédito que trabaja para Friendship Bridge. Las mujeres que integran el grupo se juntaron para formar el banco comunal y una vez conformado dicha unidad contactaron a America.

Las Parromeras contactaron la institución porque necesitan un crédito para aumentar el tamaño del capital de su negocio. La mitad del grupo va a invertir su crédito en la crianza y venta de pollos. Algunas van a comprar pollos ya crecidos para alimentarlos por unas semanas y luego venderlos. Otras van a comprar los pollos ya crecidos para destazarlos y venderlos en el mercado, mientras que otras van a comprar los pollos ya destazados y desplumados para venderlos en el mercado. Juana Martinez dice que ella no solo invierte su crédito en la crianza de pollos, sino que ella también a comprado sus cerditos para engordarlos y luego venderlos en el mercado, finalmente ella también borda blusas típicas. Uno se sorprende de la versatilidad de muchas de estas mujeres.

La otra mitad del grupo se divide en tres mujeres que venden verduras en el mercado y que invierten su crédito en la compra de zanahoria, huisquil, repollo, cebollas, tomates, lechuga, aguacate, entre otras verduras. Luego, dos mujeres trabajan en telar de pies. Ellas elaboran cortes, faldas largas tradicionales. Usualmente, solo los hombres trabajan en los telares debido a la fuerza requerida para emplear el telar. Mientras que el resto trabaja bordando blusas tradicionales de sus pueblos.

El sueño de las mujeres Parromero es el de agrandar su negocio para que así no tengan que depender de una deuda para tener un negocio rentable y para que puedan generar las suficientes utilidades para que puedan invertir en su negocio y cubrir las necesidades de sus familias. Dentro de este banco comunal hay muchas mujeres con el empuje de Juana Martinez, sin embargo muchas de estas mujeres se encuentran batallando solas, es por eso que si nosotros les demos un empuje, ellas se van a sentir acompañadas en su lucha contra la pobreza.

loans.use: To buy chickens and piglets for breeding and sale, vegetables for sale and materials for weaving and embroidering traditional blouses and skirts.

loans.name: Jorgeñitas Group

texts.es:
The women of the Jorgeñitas group come from the beautiful town of San Jorge la Laguna, a town located at the edges of the beautiful lake of Atitlán. These women reflect at first sight a confidence that calls your attention, so that while conducting the interview I was discovering the reason for this confidence.

The great majority are artisans and they work making necklaces of jewels. They produce beautiful earrings, bracelets, and necklaces with pearlites imported from the Czech Republic. Some say that this art of making necklaces was imported to lake Atitlán by European artisans several decades ago. There are also women who invest their capital in small convenience stores and knitting machines. They buy thread to create beautiful Guatemalan embroidered dresses and traditional blouses.

When the artisans begin to share how they are going to invest their loans one can realize the dimension of their businesses. The jewelers revealed that with the loan that they are going to receive they were going to buy the materials for the necklaces by the kilogram, while the great majority of artisans buy the materials for necklaces by the ounce. This reflects that they are in a little more advanced phase of business development, since the quantity of commodity that they are going to buy is a lot greater than that of the majority of artisans around la Laguna.

The Jorgeñitas have been working with Friendship Bridge for more than a year and they have benefited from the training given by the loan agents. The women commented that they were interested a lot in the themes of saving money, natural medicine and especially family planning. They mentioned what a large impact it had on them to know that a woman is able and has the authority to plan the size of her family.

Also they mentioned that they like to work with microfinance institutions, especially with Friendship Bridge, because they ask few requirements, the disbursements are fast and they help them with their business. If you contribute to the success of these artisans then they are going to be able to continue developing their qualities as businesswomen and artisans.

Translated from Spanish by B, Kiva Volunteer.

Las mujeres del grupo Jorgeñitas provienen del bello pueblo de San Jorge la Laguna. Un pueblo ubicado a las orillas del hermoso lago de Atitlán. Estas mujeres reflejan a primera vista una confianza que llama la atención, conforme fue transcurriendo la entrevista fui descubriendo el porque de esta confianza.

La gran mayoría son artesanas y trabajan elaborando joyas de mostacilla. Ellas producen hermosos aretes, brazaletes, collares con perlitas de mostacillas importadas de la República Checa. Algunos dicen que este arte de la mostacilla fue importado al lago Atitlán por artesanos Europeos hace ya varias décadas. También se encuentran mujeres que invierten su capital en pequeñas tiendas de conveniencia y tejedoras que compran hilo para elaborar bellos huipiles Guatemaltecos, blusas tradicionales.

Cuando las artesanas empezaron a compartir en que van a invertir su crédito uno se puede dar cuenta de la dimensión de su empresa. Las joyeras revelaron que con el préstamo que van a recibir iban a comprar las bolsas de mostacilla por kilo, mientras la gran mayoría de artesanas compran la mostacilla por onzas. Esto refleja que ellas están en una etapa de desarrollo empresarial un poco más avanzada, ya que la cantidad de materia prima que van a comprar es mucho mayor al de la mayoría de artesanas alrededor de la laguna.

Las Jorgeñitas han venido trabajando con Friendship Bridge por más de un año y se han beneficiado con las capacitaciones impartidas por las agentes de crédito. Las mujeres comentaban que a ellas les interesaron mucho los temas de ahorro del dinero, medicina natural y especialmente planificación familiar. Ellas mencionaron que les causó un impacto grande el hecho de conocer que una mujer puede y tiene la autorización de planificar el tamaño de su familia.

También mencionaron que les gusta trabajar con las instituciones de microfinanzas, especialmente con Friendship Bridge porque piden pocos requisitos, los desembolsos son rápidos y las ayudan con sus negocios. Si ustedes contribuyen con el éxito de estas artesanas entonces ellas van a poder seguir desarrollando sus cualidades como empresarias y artesanas.

loans.use: To buy jewels for creating necklaces, products for a convenience store and thread for weaving and embroidery.

loans.name: Sefelmira

texts.es:
The friends of Sefelmira have been working as micro-empresarios for some time. One day they convinced her to attend a seminar on micro-business organized by EDAPROSPO. She attended a little fearfully and, even with many doubts, she decided to undertake a business. Her problem was that she did not know what to sell or what to produce that would be profitable. So that she decided to learn a method of making leather sandals. At present, she has already run her business for two and a half years, working from orders that she receives from people or from some stores. She says that her better season for production and sales is the second semester of each year, when she requires the aid of two people to be able to supply the demand. Today Sefelmira does not regret starting her micro-business. With the income she can help her husband to maintain her two small children.

Translated from Spanish by B, Kiva Volunteer.

Las amigas de Sefelmira llevan más tiempo como microempresarias; un buen dia la convencieron de asistir a una capacitacion de microempresas organizada por EDAPROSPO. Ella asistio un poco temerosa y aun con muchas dudas, decidio emprender una empresa. El problema suyo era no saber qué vender o qué producir que sea rentable. Asi que decidio aprender un metodo de hacer sandalias de cuero. Actualmente, ya lleva dos años y medio trabajando segun recibe pedidos de personas o de algunas tiendas. Ella afirma que su mejor temporada de produccion y ventas es el segundo semestre de cada año, es ahi cuando requiere de la ayuda de dos personas para poder abastecerse. Hoy en dia Sefelmira no se arrepiente de haberse de animado a poner su microempresa, con los ingreso ella puede ayudar a su esposo a mantener a sus dos hijos menores.

loans.use: To buy materials for making sandals.

loans.name: Margaritas De Xesampual Group

texts.es:
When the Margaritas of Xesampual women entered the Agency of Solola I noted immediately the combination of young clients and adults inside the group. This usually forms an interesting combination, since the young women tend to listen to the oldest in "compromising" situations, such as when one asks a question in Spanish and the adult women tend to share their know-how with the younger women in moments during the training. Also, a combination of businesswomen and novices C. be found. This combination is something very valuable, since the experience and "tips" that C. be shared benefit the women without so much experience in business.

The great majority of associates inside this group work in the clothes business. They sell clothes, whether traditional clothes such as long skirts called cortes, typical embroidered blouses called huipiles, cinchos or straps, perrajes or scarves and blouses. Also some women resell western clothes inside their town. They buy these clothes buy in the capital or in the regional capitals in order then to sell them in their towns. In the group there is also one associate that has a shoe store.

One of the ladies that sell blouses said that she was going to invest all her loan to buy twenty dozen blouses at Q150 each dozen in order then to resell them for Q180. Another mentioned that with the Q3000 that she was going to receive, she was going to buy five dozen shoes to supply the inventory of her store. The initiatives and quantities vary depending on the businesswoman and the size of their business.

Something that does not vary a lot is the importance they put on covering the needs of their families and their children. Among the basic needs of each client are the expense of food, a college scholarship and gas or firewood. Nevertheless, the largest expense for all the clients is that of food. Feeding their extensive families is not an easy task.

Generating sufficient income in a small town to cover the expenses of an extensive family and also to have money to reinvest in the business is a difficult task. That is why support is important to these women; so that they C. continue doing well with their business and support their families.

Translated from Spanish by B, Kiva Volunteer.

Cuando las mujeres Margaritas de Xesampual entraron a la Agencia de Solola pude notar inmediatamente la combinación de clientes jóvenes y adultas dentro del grupo. Esto usualmente forma una combinación interesante ya que las mujeres jóvenes tienden a asistir a las más adultas en situación “comprometedoras” como cuando uno le hace una pregunta en español y las mujeres adultas tienden a compartir sus conocimientos con las más jovencitas en los momentos de las capacitación. También, se puede encontrar una combinación de empresarias consolidadas y principiantes. Esta combinación es algo muy valioso, ya que las experiencias y “tips” se pueden compartir beneficiando a las mujeres sin tanta experiencia en el negocio.

La gran mayoría de clientas dentro de este grupo trabaja en el negocio de la ropa. Ellas venden ropa, ya sea ropa tradicional como faldas largas llamadas cortes, blusas típicas llamadas huipiles, cinchos o correas, perrajes y blusas. También se encuentran las mujeres que revenden ropa occidental dentro de su pueblo. Aquella ropa la compran en la capital o en las cabeceras departamentales para luego venderlas en sus pueblos. En el grupo tenemos una clienta que tiene una zapatería.

Una de las señoras que venden blusas dijo que iba a invertir todo su préstamo comprar veinte docenas de blusas a Q150 cada docena para luego revenderla a Q180. Otra mencionó que con los Q3000 que iba a prestar iba a comprar cinco docenas de zapatos para surtir el inventario de su tienda. Las iniciativas y cantidades varían dependiendo de la empresaria y el tamaño de sus negocios.

Algo que no varia mucho es la importancia de cubrir las necesidades de sus familias y sus hijos. Entre las necesidades básicas de cada clienta están el gasto de la comida, la colegiatura y el gas o la leña. Sin embargo, el gasto más fuerte de todas las clientas es el de la comida. Alimentar a sus extensas familias no es una tarea fácil.

Generar la suficiente cantidad de ingresos en un pequeño para cubrir los gastos de una familia extensa y además tener dinero para reinvertirlo en el negocio es una difícil tarea. Es por eso que poyar a estas mujeres es importante para que así ellas puedan seguir saliendo adelante con sus negocios y apoyar a sus familias.

loans.use: To buy clothes and shoes for resale.

loans.name: Rosas Rojas Group

texts.es:
Behind the look of a group of timid women one never knows what experiences can be found and in this case business initiatives also.

The Red Roses group explained to me something that I would never have been able to contemplate and that is that, without an infusion of capital, they would not be able to create their own separate business. Without the loan they would continue being employees of someone else, earning a minimum wage which would not give them enough to either begin a career or leave poverty.

Nevertheless, the adult women told me that at the moment of receiving a loan they are touched, but at the same time they feel a little fear because they do not know if they are going to be able repay the debt. It is a very understandable feeling since is a new experience through which they and all the women of their generation are passing. In spite of that, they have already completed five loans with Friendship Bridge.

A detail that leaps to light was that the majority of members of this group worked selling second-hand items. Four clients commented that they went to the city of Guatemala, a trip of approximately four hours, to buy second-hand items in order to sell them in Suchitepequez which is a regional capital that is located to another four hours from the town of Nahuala. The interesting thing about these trips is that the women travel to completely different destinations and therefore compete with people from other cultures that are not theirs. This is something really impressive since traditionally the women are confined inside a native community and do not tend to travel a lot. Another detail that reflects a modernist cut of this group is that ten women among the youths and adults have just bought cell phones.

Two clients will invest their credit in wood to work in carpentry. Two others have a bakery. Others sell and weave clothes. As can be seen in this group one can find a variety of important businesses.

The Red Roses is a group of women that is exploring different roads, so that in some way they can avoid being faced with the saturation of the market by opting for businesses that have not been explored by the remainder of women in their communities. Supporting a group of creative and innovative women is important to promote the development of micro-business and of Guatemala. Thanks for your consideration.

Translated from Spanish by B, Kiva Volunteer.

Detrás la mirada de un grupo de mujeres tímidas uno nunca sabe que experiencias puede extraer de ellas y en este caso iniciativas empresariales también.

Las Rosas Rojas me explicaron algo que nunca hubiera podido contemplar y eso es que sin infusión de capital, su negocio no podría despegar. Sin el crédito ellas seguirían siendo empleadas de alguien más ganando una cantidad mínima la cual no las dejaría ni empezar la carrera de salir de la pobreza.

Sin embargo, las mujeres adultas me comentaron que a la hora de sacar un crédito ellas se emocionan, pero a la vez sienten un poco de temor porque no van a saber si van a poder repagar la deuda. Es un sentimiento muy entendible ya que es una experiencia nueva por las cuales ellas y todas las mujeres de su generación están pasando. A pesar de eso, ya llevaban con Friendship Bridge cinco créditos.

Un detalle que salto a luz fue que la mayoría de integrantes de este grupo trabajaban vendiendo trastes. Cuatro clientas comentaron que se iban a la ciudad de Guatemala un viaje de aproximadamente cuatro horas a comprar trastes para luego irlos a vender hasta Suchitepequez la cual es una cabecera departamental que está ubicada a otras cuatro horas del pueblo de Nahuala. Lo interesante de estos viajes es que las mujeres viajan a destinos completamente distintos y por ende lidiando con gente de otras culturas que no son las suyas. Algo realmente impresionante ya que tradicionalmente las mujeres dentro de una comunidad indígena están confinadas y no tienden a viajar mucho. Otro detalle que refleja un corte vanguardista de este grupo es que diez mujeres entre jóvenes y adultas acaban de comprar celulares.

Dos clientas invierten su crédito en madera para trabajar en carpintería. Otras dos tienen un panadería, otras venden y tejen ropa. Como se puede ver en este grupo uno puede encontrar una variedad de negocios importante.

Las Rojas Rosas es un grupo de mujeres que está explorando distintos caminos, que de alguna manera están evitando enfrentarse a la saturación de mercado al optar por negocios no muy explorado por el resto de mujeres en sus comunidades. Apoyar a un grupo de mujeres innovadoras y creativas es importante para promover el desarrollo de la microempresa y de Guatemala. Gracias por tomarlas en cuenta.

loans.use: To buy seond-hand items and clothes for resale, thread for weaving, supplies for a bakery, products for a convenience store, and wood for carpentry.

loans.name: Estrellas Group

texts.es:
The “Estrellas” Association is located in the center of Villa Tejada. Headed by its president, Mrs. Carmiña Gutiérrez, they have shown themselves to be an accomplished and organized group. Said group is comprised of sixteen members who have worked for more than one year with Pro-Mujer. The primary activity of these women is retail, dedicating themselves to the sale of vegetables, handmade chocolates, ice cream, and cell phone cases. They market their products in an ambulatory manner, given they do not count on established sites from which to sell their wares. The group needs additional capital to lease a stall/stand where they can be assured of making transactions. In this manner, they would generate more income to help improve the financial situation of their households.

Translated from Spanish by Mary Lynn, Kiva Volunteer.

La asociación “Estrellas” pertenece al centro focal de Villa Tejada, a la cabeza de la Sra. Carmiña Gutiérrez como presidenta demuestran ser un grupo cumplido y organizado. El mencionado grupo esta formado por 16 socias que trabajan hace mas de un año con Pro-Mujer. El comercio informal es la actividad principal de estas mujeres, se dedican a la venta de fruta, chocolates artesanales, helados, estuches de celulares, productos que por lo general los ofrecen de manera ambulante, ya que no cuentan con puestos propios de venta por lo que necesitan mayor capital para el alquiler o compra de dichos puestos de venta lo que les aseguraría una venta segura de sus productos. De esta forma generarian mayores ingresos para mejorar la economia de sus hogares.

loans.use: Capital to lease and/or purchase their own stalls.

loans.name: 15 De Diciembre Group

texts.es:
It’s been about 4 years approximately that the “15 de Diciembre” association has belonged to the Pro-Mujer family. They are a group of 18 women who work toward improving their standards of living. Almost all are married and have an average of seven children of varied ages. The principal activity of this group is agriculture, such as growing potatoes, beans, oca, carrots and others, which they harvest each month. They sell the aforementioned products at the La Ceja market (city of El Alto). Unfortunately, the frosts in winter caused them to lose a few of their crops, which is why they need capital to invest into new harvests to generate income that would allow them to recover their previously lost investment. In addition, the loan would be to generate income to help sustain their families on a daily basis.

Translated from Spanish by Mary Lynn, Kiva Volunteer.

Hace cuatro años aproximadamente la asociación 15 de diciembre pertenece a la familia de Pro-Mujer, grupo formado por 18 mujeres que trabajan con la ilusión de mejorar su estilo de vida. Casi todas casadas y con un promedio de 7 hijos, de distintas edades. La actividad principal de éste grupo es la agricultura, la papa, haba, oca, zanahorias y otros, son productos que cosechan mensualmente. Los mencionados productos los venden en el mercado de la Ceja (ciudad de El Alto), solo en días de feria. Lamentablemente las heladas del pronto invierno han hecho que pierdan algunas cosechas, por esto necesitan capital para invertir en nuevas cosechas, para generar ingresos que les permita recuperar la inversión perdida, además de generar ingresos para el sustento diario de estas familias

loans.use: To reinforce their capital for future harvests.

loans.name: Uk´ux´kem Group

texts.es:
Entering the meeting place of the women who make up the Uk´Ux Kem Group, one can feel the difference between this group and the average communal bank. In my case, I observed a cheerful environment that involved such riotous laughter at one point that we had to pause briefly before continuing with my interview! This resulted when I asked for a show of hands from those women present who raised farm animals. The translator told them to raise their hands if they were animals.

The Uk´Ux Kem ladies are unequalled in their sense of joy, which is reflected in the manner in which they work and use their credit. It appears all the group members feel a loan helps them better themselves business-wise, given that this increases their working capital and grows their small businesses.

The majority of the members invest their loan in fabric. Many create beautiful traditional blouses called “huipiles”. In addition, they also use the same creative techniques to make cloth napkins, table coverings, and other items for interior decorating. The other part of the group uses the credit to raise livestock to be sold at the market. This is a good business in rural areas where large enterprises in this arena have not yet arrived at the markets.

You will find several outstanding businesswomen among this group. For example, Mrs. Candelaria H. told me she was currently employing three women to make cortes, a traditional skirt, and another woman to make cloth napkins. Mrs. Albina Yiax commented that she raises chickens, and uses their waste to fertilize her maize crop.

Interviewing this group of women was a pleasure and wonderful assignment because they are hard-working ladies who, despite their difficult situations, keep a lovely smile on their faces. It is for this reason that you must provide them with your support.

Translated from Spanish by Mary Lynn, Kiva Volunteer.

Entrando al lugar de reunión de las mujeres que conforman el grupo Uk´Ux Kem uno puede sentir la diferencia entre este grupo y un banco comunal promedio. En mi caso, pude sentir un ambiente alegre que se materializó en risa incontrolables que hasta en un punto ¡llegaron a ser un breve impedimento para proseguir con la entrevista! Este punto llegó cuando les peí a las compañeras que levantaran la mano las que criaban animales y la traductora les dijo que levantaron la mano las que son animales.

Las mujeres Uk´Ux Kem no solo son inigualables en el sentido de la alegría que reflejan sino en la manera como trabajan y utilizan el crédito. Al parecer, todas las clientas creen que el crédito las ayuda a superarse empresarialmente, ya que les ayuda a aumentar su capital y por ende agrandar su pequeño negocio.

La mayoría de ellas invierten su dinero en tejido. Muchas siguen elaborando bellas blusas típicas llamadas huipiles. Asimismo, ellas también elaboran usando la misma técnica servilletas, caminos de mesa, entre otras cositas para el interior de las casas. Otro grupo de mujeres utilizan el crédito para criar animales y luego venderlos en el mercado. Este es un buen negocio en las área rurales en donde grandes empresas, dentro de esta industria, todavía no entran al mercado.

En este grupo se puede encontrar varias empresarias destacadas. Por ejemplo Doña Candelaria H. contó que ella estaba actualmente contratando a tres mujeres para que tejan cortes, una falda tradicional, y una mujer para que teja servilletas. Doña Albina Yiax comentó que ella criaba pollos y que las eses fecales son utilizadas para abonar su milpa o cosecha de maíz.

Entrevistar a este grupo de mujeres fue un placer y a la misma vez una linda hazaña porque son personas luchadoras y que a pesar de su difícil situación ellas mantienen una bella sonrisa. Es por eso ,que se les tiene que apoyar.

loans.use: Purchase fabric to make traditional outfits, and investing in the necessities for raising livestock.

loans.name: Female Workers Group

texts.es:
The association of “Female Workers” has been a part of Pro-Mujer for more than 5 years. They have received and repaid 8 loans. The group lives in the Villa Tejada zone of El Alto and has 13 active members. The group has proven itself to be very organized.

The majority of the women do not own there homes. Instead, they pay monthly rent for small rooms which are insufficient for the needs of their families. These members need to save money in order to achieve the dream of owning their own homes.

The principal industry of the group is the production of artesian goods, including furniture, shoes, ceramics, paintings, etc. The women need additional capital in order to expand their workshops and purchase additional material for their work. In expanding their stores and inventories they will be able to increase their sales.

Translate from Spanish by Casey Unrein, Kiva volunteer.

La asociación denominada “Obreras” pertenece a la familia de Pro-Mujer hace ya cinco años cumpliendo con 8 ciclos de crédito, esta se encuentra en la zona de Villa Tejada, de la ciudad de El Alto, a la fecha cuenta con 13 socias activas que han demostrado ser un grupo organizado en cuanto al trabajo del centro. Una gran parte de ellas no cuenta con casa propia lo que les lleva a pagar alquileres mensuales de pequeños ambientes que no les son suficientes para sus numerosas familias Teniendo la necesidad de ahorrar dinero con el sueño de comprar una casita propia. La artesanía es la actividad principal de este grupo, produciendo así, muebles, zapatos, cerámicas, pinturas, y otros. Necesitan de mayor capital para ampliar sus talleres y comprar mayor cantidad de materia prima de esta manera sus ganancias serian mayores.

loans.use: Expand their workshops and purchase additional material.

loans.name: Deissi Alejendrin

texts.en:
Deissi Alejendrin R. G. has a business selling cosmetics in the town of Salpo, high in the Sierras of the Region of La Libertad. She sells her products in Salpo and also often travels to Trujillo where she has a few loyal customers. She buys and sells Esiak products, a popular brand in Peru.

Deissi is 37 years old, single, and has 2 children. Her business has given her the ability to provide for her children and improve her self confidence. She now has ideas to start other businesses.

A member of the community bank Virgen de Las Mercedes, Deissi is requesting a loan of s/2200 to repay over 6 months and will restock many of the popular cosmetics her clients enjoy.

loans.use: To restock many of the popular cosmetics her clients enjoy.

loans.name: Yolanda Del Rio Group

texts.es:
In the Villa Adela zone of El Alto is located a community center which carries the same name. The association of women, “Yolanda of the River,” belongs to this community center and has 16 members. It is a very friendly group of women, who have grown to be very tightly knit over the time they have worked with Pro-Mujer and received loans.

The group members work in several different industries. One woman owns a small hair salon (a trade she learned from her mother), another sells food. The majority of the women however, produce clothing. They sew blouses, pants, skirts, jerseys, etc. The women sew all these items on their own, and learned to do so in the training facilities of Pro-Mujer.

The women are requesting this loan in order to purchase fabric. With additional fabric the women will be able to expand their businesses and obtain individual shops in order to sell their goods in a more formal manner.

Translate from Spanish by Casey Unrein, Kiva volunteer.

En la zona de villa Adela, se encuentra ubicado el centro focal delmismo nombre, a este pertenece la asociación “Yolanda del río” cuenta con16 socias. Un grupo muy simpático y particular ya que además de trabajar juntas con el sistema de créditos que pro-mujer les sofrece, llegaron a formar una muy linda amistad entre ellas. Las actividades que realiza la asociación “Yolanda del río” son de todo tipo alguna de ellas tiene un pequeño salón de peinados, negocio que aprendió de su madre, venta de comida, pero la mayoría se dedica a la confección de ropa como ser: blusas, pantalones polleras, buzos deportivos y otros, estos artilcuos son confeccionados por ellas mismas ya que ellas aprendieron el oficio de la confeccion en los talleres de capacitacion que Pro-Mujer ofrece. Afirman que necesitan mayor capital para la compra de telas, asi poder expandir su negocio y adquirir puestos propios para ofrecer sus productos de manera más formal.

loans.use: Purchase of additional fabric in order to expand their businesses and obtain individual shops in order to sell their goods in a more formal manner.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: Purchase yarn for traditional weavings, resell traditional and American-style clothes

loans.name: Isturah

texts.id:
Mrs. Isturah makes and sells krupuk (a popular snack made of fried flower pronounced 'crew-pook'). Every day she goes to the market at 6AM to purchase ingredients. These include flour, peanuts and chicken intestines (for making broth). She must purchase at least 8kg of goods at a cost of 7,000Rp/Kg. When she returns home, her husband Mohammad Najib helps her to fry and package the krupuk. Afterwards, she travels to various small shops and restaurants along Kartini Denpasar Street to sell them. The money she makes is used to pay for her children's schooling and to help meet the day-to-day needs of her family. Mrs. Isturah really hopes she can get help with her business.

Translated from Bahasa Indonesia by Courtenay Teska Race, Kiva Volunteer.

Profesi yang dijalani Ibu Isturah sekarang ini adalah sebagai penjual krupuk. Setiap hari, Isturah sudah harus ke pasar pukul 06.00 pagi untuk membeli bahan-bahan untuk membuat krupuk berupa tepung, kacang dan usus ayam. Biasanya dia membeli sebanyak 8 kg dengan per kg Rp.7.000.- Setelah itu, dibantu oleh suaminya Mohammad Najib, Isturah menggoreng krupuk tersebut dan setelah jadi kemudian dibungkus lalu diedarkan warung-warung dan kantin-kantin yang ada disekitar tempat tinggalnya di Jl.Kartini Denpasar. Keuntungan yang didapat dari berjualan krupuk dipaki sebagai biaya menyekolahkan anaknya dan juga mencukupi kebutuhan keluarga. Isturah sangat berharap mendapatkan bantuan sebagai tambahan modal usaha.

loans.use: to increase funding for her business

loans.name: Dilorom

texts.ru:
Dilorom has been selling on the market for the past five years. She is married and has two children. She used to work as a school teacher, but her salary was not enough to support the family. Her husband lost his job and began working as a a repairman. She received a loan once to increase the assortment of her merchandise. Dilorom brings in the merchandise from Bishkek. After eceiving a loan she brought in the summer clothes. She is very happy that she got the loan on time and she will have better sales of her seasonal merchandise.

Translated from Russian by Elena Fedorchuk, Kiva Volunteer.

В течении 5 лет Дилором торгует на рынке, она замужем имеет 2 детей. Она раньше работала учительницей в средней школе, но оклад школы не хватал , что бы содержать семью. Муж тоже потерял работу, он начал работать мастером ремонтных работ. Она получила кредит для увеличения ассортимента детской одежды. Дилором привозит новый товар из Бишкека. Получив кредит, она привезла товар летнего сезона. Она рада, что вовремя получила кредит и у нее будет хорошая реализация товара.

loans.use: Сhildren clothes

payments.comment: Correction due to overpayment for business 47411

loans.name: Soonaalofa

texts.en:
Soonaalofa is 40 years old, married, with 3 children. She comes from a poor family background. Through the years they used to live on their family plantation, but when Samoa was hit by taro blight, it destroyed most of the plantations on the island. Her husband used to do carpentry work, but he was recently laid off due to company bankruptcy. Soonaalofa heard of SPBD through women of her village and she decided to join. This is her first loan She’s very thankful for such a great opportunity where she is able to improve her family's living.

Her loan will be used to purchase baking materials for pancakes (deep-fried dough) and ice cakes (ice cream) to be sold to the local villagers and school children.

loans.use: To purchase baking powder, sugar, flour, plastic, etc.

loans.name: Eneleka

texts.en:
Eneleka operates a small grocery store where she sells drinks, snacks, twisties, lollies, tins of herring, and various other products needed by her customers. She has already made two other expansions to her shop. She lives on the seaside of one of the villages. She is a 34-year-old mother of eight children; six live in Samoa and two reside overseas, but they all support their mother's business.

Eneleka's goal was to improve their standard of living, and for her children to get a better education and better access to proper health care. Eneleka joined SPBD in 2004; she is now on her 3rd loan. She puts the profits from her business into her savings account with SPBD to assist in refilling the stock of the business if any week is too slow.

loans.use: Purchase a new supply of goods

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary is 50 years old and is a widow with 3 children, ages 18,16 and 14 years old. She also takes care of 4 other children, ages 15, 13 and 9 years old. Mary owns a small pharmacy store which she started in 2002. Everyday, she works from 8am to 6pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $250 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more medicine for her business.

loans.use: To buy more medicine for her business.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Tanzania - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Norbeta's Group

texts.en:
Norbeta is 28 years old and is a married woman with 2 children, ages 8 and 2 years old. She and her husband also take care of 2 other children, who are both 16 years old. Norbeta sells charcoal. She started in 2007. Every day, she works from 8am to 6pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $35 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more charcoal for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members, Anna and Helen, who have operate a cafe.

loans.use: To buy more charcoal for her business.

loans.name: Fediria

texts.en: Fediria is 40 years old and is a married woman with 2 children, ages 10  and 7 years old. Fediria sells local beer. She started in 2008. Every day, she works from 11am to 8pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $35 from her sales. She now hopes for a loan to buy more beer for her business.

loans.use: To buy more beer for her business.

loans.name: Sakina's Tuamke Group

texts.en:
Sakina is 37 years old and is a married woman with 7 children. She and her husband also take care of 2 other children, ages 15 and 12 years old. Sakina is a tailor. She started in 2006. Every day, she works from 7am to 8pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $90 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more tailoring items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members, Adela, Grace, Hawa, Asha and Siwema, who have businesses selling charcoal and port, and operating a beauty salon and a restaurant.

loans.use: To buy more tailoring items for her business.

loans.name: Clementina's Tuamke Group

texts.en:
Clementina is 24 years old and is married woman with 1 child, age 2 years old. She and her husband also take care of 2 other children, ages 14 and 16 years old. Clementina sells chips and food items to the market. Every day, she works from 8 a.m. to 10 p.m. at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $60 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more food items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup member Herena, who has business dealing in chips, chicken and egg sales.

loans.use: To buy  food items for her businesss.

loans.name: Amina

texts.en:
Amina is 32 years old and is a married woman with 3 children, ages 6 and 1 year old. She and her husband also take care of 2 other people, ages 48 and 50 years old. Amina owns a small general store and she is market seller, which she started in 2007. Every day, she works from 8 am to 8.30 pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $200 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more items for her business.

loans.use: To buy more items for her business.

loans.name: Pili

texts.en:
Mambo from Mwanza, Tanzania! This is 35 year-old Pili M.. She is married, and has five children between the ages of 2 and 11. Pili owns a tailoring business. She earns about US $90 every month from this business. Pili requires a loan in order to purchase stocks of cloth and sewing accessories in bulk. She thanks you for your support.

SELFINA is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility as a practical way to achieve the economic and social emancipation of women.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets. The lack of tangible collateral assets means they are deemed not-creditworthy by financial institutions, restricting access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes.

SELFINA buys and leases equipment to women. Where a client needs working capital, SELFINA buys equipment from said client, extends a loan to her, then leases back the same equipment – a process called a sale and leaseback arrangement.

loans.use: To purchase stocks of cloth and  sewing accessories in bulk.

loans.name: Mwanahawa

texts.en:
Mwanahawa is 38 years old and is a married woman with 5 children, ages 1 to 18 years old. Mwanahawa is a market seller, and she started in 1990. Everyday, she works from 7 am to 6 pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $50 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more market items for her business.

loans.use: To buy more market items for her business.

loans.name: Devotha's Ari Mpya Group

texts.en:
Devotha is 27 years old and is a married woman with 2 children, ages 8 and 2 years old. She and her husband also take care of 2 other people, ages 54 and 13 years old. Devotha sells clothes, shoes and handbags, and she started in 2006. Every day, she works from 9 am to 6 pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $90 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to open a storefront for selling clothes, shoes and handbags. She will share this loan with her subgroup members Tumaini and Mariam, who have businesses dealing in stationery sales and a salon.

loans.use: To open a storefront for selling clothes, shoes, and handbags.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Tanzania - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Consolatha's Ari Mpya Group

texts.en:
Consolatha is 27 years old and is married woman with 2 children, ages 11 and 7 years old. Consolatha sells clothes and soap, and she started in 2006. Every day, she works from 8 am to 6 pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $70 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more clothes (khanga, a cultural favorite) and soap for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members Magreth, Rehema and Yusta, who have businesses dealing in general store, clothes & charcoal sales, and market materials sales.

loans.use: To buy clothes (khanga) and soap for her business.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Tanzania - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Consolatha's Ari Mpya Group

texts.en:
Consolatha is 27 years old and is married woman with 2 children, ages 11 and 7 years old. Consolatha sales clothes and soap, she started in 2006. Everyday, she works from 8am to 6pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $70 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more clothes (khanga) and soap for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members Magreth, Rehema and Yusta, who have businesses dealing in general store,clothes & charcoal sales,and marker materials sales.

loans.use: To buy clothes (khanga) and soap fpr her business.

loans.name: Suja'i

texts.id:
Suja'i, his wife and children live on Mertasari Suwung Street. Suja'i's business is in buying recyclables from the residents in his area and selling them to the recycle centers. Suja'i has already received one loan through Kiva/DINARI which he paid back on time. He thanks God that the last loan he received helped him grow his business. He really hopes he can receive another loan because he already has more customers who would like to sell him their recyclables, but needs more capitol to afford it. Suja'i uses the profits from his business to pay for his children to go to school.

Translated from Bahasa Indonesia by Courtenay Teska Race, Kiva Volunteer.

Bertempat di Jl.Mertasari Suwung, Suja’i tinggal bersama istri dan anak-anaknya. Usaha yang dijalani masih sebagai pemulung atau pengepul barang-barang bekas yang dibeli dari masyarakat sekitar. Sebelumnya Suja’i sudah pernah menjadi klien DINARI, dengan pembayaran yang tepat waktu. Kali ini merupakan pinjaman yang kedua, dan Suja’i sangat bersyukur karena dari pinjamannya yang pertama usahanya sudah mengalami perkembangan. Suja’i berharap kali ini bisa mendapatkan pinjaman lagi karena dia sudah mendapatkan beberapa pelanggan baru yang siap menjual barang-barang bekas kepadanya. Dia berharap keuntungannya bisa dipakai untuk menyekolahkan anak-anaknya.

loans.use: to increase funding for his business

loans.name: Aksa

texts.en:
Aksa is 37 years old and is a single woman with 2 children, ages 17 and 13 years old. Aksa sells clothes, and she started in 2004. Every day, she works from 8 am to 6 pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $250 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more clothes (khanga and vitenge) for her business.

loans.use: To buy more clothes (khanga and vitenge, cultural favorites) for her business.

loans.name: Selestina's Ari Mpya Group

texts.en:
Selestina is 34 years old and is a married woman with 2 children, ages 4 and 7 years old. Selestina is a tailor and charcoal seller, and she started in 2006. Every day, she works from 8 am to 6 pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $40 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more tailoring items and charcoal for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members Genetha, Lilian, Martha and Zena, who have businesses dealing in a general store, clothes sales and market materials sales.

loans.use: To buy more tailoring items and charcoal for her business.

loans.name: Johari's Ari Mpya Group

texts.en:
Johari is 24 years old and is a single woman with 2 children. Johari sales ugali, rice, sausage and meat, and she started in 2007. Every day, she works from 7 am to 6 pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $90 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more food items (bananas, maize flour, rice and meat) for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members Mwasiti, Tausi and Jasmini, who have businesses dealing in food vending, soap & charcoal sales and a general store owner.

loans.use: To buy more food items (bananas, maize flour, rice and meat) for her business.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Tanzania - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Ni Ketut

texts.id:
The price of cooking oil has gone up, but that has not stopped Ni Ketut from continuing her business selling chicken-foot krupuk (a snack made of fried chicken feet). Every morning at 5AM Ni Ketut, who lives on Raya Sading Street, goes to Sempidi Market to purchase chicken feet. After returning to her house she boils the chicken feet for an hour. After they cool she removes the skin and bones and lets them sit. Once they are dry, she fries them and packages them up. By the late afternoon the krupuk are ready for selling to small restaurants in the area. Ni Ketut uses the profits from her business to pay for her children to go to school and to to pay for the day-to-day needs of her family.

Translated from Bahasa Indonesia by Courtenay Teska Race, Kiva Volunteer.
